values.title: Indentation might not be indented enough

content.raw: In the expanded right column, it's hard to tell where one section ends and the next begins. Perhaps make each section collapsible so that you can see just one section at a time on the right. And/or, make the indentation more dramatic.
content.html: In the expanded right column, it's hard to tell where one section ends and the next begins. Perhaps make each section collapsible so that you can see just one section at a time on the right. And/or, make the indentation more dramatic.

values.title: Make schema for validation
create "static" meta-tag

content.raw: It would be very useful to be able to set the static flag for a model when including it. Otherwise there's no way to make an object static or not static without changing the model definition file. For example some people might want to use a bookshelf as static while others want it to be dynamic.
content.html: It would be very useful to be able to set the static flag for a model when including it. Otherwise there's no way to make an object static or not static without changing the model definition file. For example some people might want to use a bookshelf as static while others want it to be dynamic.

values.title: sdflog not yet implemented

content.raw:
The `sdflog` stream is currently directed to `/dev/null` ([see src/Console.cc:53-74](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/552cce2356962f00b95c4d2f77048982a3e1c570/src/Console.cc?at=default#cl-53)).

The `sdflog` stream is needed to port changes to parser.cc from [gazebo pull request 533](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/533) and [pull request 568](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/568).
content.html:
The sdflog stream is currently directed to /dev/null (see src/Console.cc:53-74).

The sdflog stream is needed to port changes to parser.cc from gazebo pull request 533 and pull request 568.

values.title: Installation will fail on case-insensitive filesystems

content.raw:
This package installs `sdf/sdf.hh` and `sdf/SDF.hh` in the include folders. This will not be possible on filesystems that are not case-sensitive. Note that this includes Mac OS X, which by default uses a case-preserving but not case-sensitive filesystem.

Note that this was not an issue when the sdf code was in gazebo because `SDF.hh` was installed to `sdf/interface/SDF.hh`.
content.html:
This package installs sdf/sdf.hh and sdf/SDF.hh in the include folders. This will not be possible on filesystems that are not case-sensitive. Note that this includes Mac OS X, which by default uses a case-preserving but not case-sensitive filesystem.

Note that this was not an issue when the sdf code was in gazebo because SDF.hh was installed to sdf/interface/SDF.hh.

values.title: SDFConfig.cmake is broken

content.raw:
The package name and high-level directories were renamed in pull request #17. This included renaming `SDFConfig.cmake` to `SDFormatConfig.cmake`. The pull request says that it "leaves behind the old SDFConfig.cmake and sdf.pc files to allow current code to keep building for one release cycle."

The `SDFConfig.cmake` is broken though, since it is a renamed copy of `SDFormatConfig.cmake`, and all the internal variables are prefixed with sdformat rather than sdf. I'm pasting the `SDFConfig.cmake` below from the sdf-1.4.4 deb to illustrate this:
~~~
if (SDFormat_CONFIG_INCLUDED)
  return()
endif()
set(SDFormat_CONFIG_INCLUDED TRUE)

list(APPEND SDFormat_INCLUDE_DIRS /usr/include/sdformat-1.4)

list(APPEND SDFormat_CFLAGS -I/usr/include/sdformat-1.4)

foreach(lib sdformat)
  set(onelib "${lib}-NOTFOUND")
  find_library(onelib ${lib}
    PATHS /usr/lib
    NO_DEFAULT_PATH
    )
  if(NOT onelib)
    message(FATAL_ERROR "Library '${lib}' in package SDFormat is not installed properly")
  endif()
  list(APPEND SDFormat_LIBRARIES ${onelib})
endforeach()

foreach(dep Boost)
  if(NOT ${dep}_FOUND)
    find_package(${dep})
  endif()
  list(APPEND SDFormat_INCLUDE_DIRS ${${dep}_INCLUDE_DIRS})
  list(APPEND SDFormat_LIBRARIES ${${dep}_LIBRARIES})
endforeach()

list(APPEND SDFormat_LDFLAGS -L/usr/lib)
~~~
content.html:
The package name and high-level directories were renamed in pull request #17. This included renaming SDFConfig.cmake to SDFormatConfig.cmake. The pull request says that it "leaves behind the old SDFConfig.cmake and sdf.pc files to allow current code to keep building for one release cycle."

The SDFConfig.cmake is broken though, since it is a renamed copy of SDFormatConfig.cmake, and all the internal variables are prefixed with sdformat rather than sdf. I'm pasting the SDFConfig.cmake below from the sdf-1.4.4 deb to illustrate this:

if (SDFormat_CONFIG_INCLUDED)
  return()
endif()
set(SDFormat_CONFIG_INCLUDED TRUE)

list(APPEND SDFormat_INCLUDE_DIRS /usr/include/sdformat-1.4)

list(APPEND SDFormat_CFLAGS -I/usr/include/sdformat-1.4)

foreach(lib sdformat)
  set(onelib "${lib}-NOTFOUND")
  find_library(onelib ${lib}
    PATHS /usr/lib
    NO_DEFAULT_PATH
    )
  if(NOT onelib)
    message(FATAL_ERROR "Library '${lib}' in package SDFormat is not installed properly")
  endif()
  list(APPEND SDFormat_LIBRARIES ${onelib})
endforeach()

foreach(dep Boost)
  if(NOT ${dep}_FOUND)
    find_package(${dep})
  endif()
  list(APPEND SDFormat_INCLUDE_DIRS ${${dep}_INCLUDE_DIRS})
  list(APPEND SDFormat_LIBRARIES ${${dep}_LIBRARIES})
endforeach()

list(APPEND SDFormat_LDFLAGS -L/usr/lib)

values.title: Cannot override element values for lights included using the <include> tag

content.raw:
overriding works for models, but not lights

problem is that the parser only looks for `<model>` elements as shown in this [line](
#!/osrf/sdformat/src/8cfd2155d0397f0bc8cebadb09e6b241994c4950/src/parser.cc?at=default#cl-629). 

Should check if it's model or light before overriding values
content.html:
overriding works for models, but not lights

problem is that the parser only looks for <model> elements as shown in this line.

Should check if it's model or light before overriding values

values.title: parser_urdf accidentally shares gazebo extensions across different models

content.raw:
parser_urdf.cc declares g_extensions at the global level ([L37](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3c73f4c32d8c20e368c583ddbbc791bf37f14331/src/parser_urdf.cc?at=sdf_1.4#cl-37)):
```
#!c++

std::map<std::string, std::vector<SDFExtension*> > g_extensions;
```

When I load 2 robots with the same visual plugin as below:
```
#!xml

    <gazebo reference="${name}_screen_link">
      <visual>
        <plugin name="${name}_video_controller" filename="libgazebo_ros_video.so">
          <height>120</height>
          <width>160</width>
          <topicName>image</topicName>
        </plugin>
      </visual>
    </gazebo>
```

The program crashes out with the following error:
```
gzserver: tinyxml.cpp:165: TiXmlNode* TiXmlNode::LinkEndChild(TiXmlNode*): Assertion `node->parent == 0 || node->parent == this' failed.
#3  0x00007ffff4f6a192 in __GI___assert_fail (
    assertion=0x7ffff4605600 "node->parent == 0 || node->parent == this", 
    file=0x7ffff460546a "tinyxml.cpp", line=165, 
    function=0x7ffff4605740 "TiXmlNode* TiXmlNode::LinkEndChild(TiXmlNode*)") at assert.c:103
#4  0x00007ffff45fea15 in TiXmlNode::LinkEndChild(TiXmlNode*) () from /usr/lib/libtinyxml.so.2.6.2
#5  0x00007ffff5ee1ab7 in InsertSDFExtensionVisual(TiXmlElement*, std::string const&) ()
   from /usr/lib/libsdformat.so.1
#6  0x00007ffff5ee9990 in CreateVisual(TiXmlElement*, boost::shared_ptr<urdf::Link const>, boost::shared_ptr<urdf::Visual>, std::string const&) () from /usr/lib/libsdformat.so.1
```

I think this can be resolved by calling `g_extensions.clear()` in `InitModelString`, though I am not sure if there are any other ramifications of doing so (should be added right before [L2552](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/3c73f4c32d8c20e368c583ddbbc791bf37f14331/src/parser_urdf.cc?at=sdf_1.4#cl-2552)). As far as I can tell `g_extensions` should be used once per model and is only global for code convenience.
content.html:
parser_urdf.cc declares g_extensions at the global level (L37):

std::map<std::string, std::vector<SDFExtension*> > g_extensions;

When I load 2 robots with the same visual plugin as below:

    <gazebo reference="${name}_screen_link">
      <visual>
        <plugin name="${name}_video_controller" filename="libgazebo_ros_video.so">
          <height>120</height>
          <width>160</width>
          <topicName>image</topicName>
        </plugin>
      </visual>
    </gazebo>

The program crashes out with the following error:

gzserver: tinyxml.cpp:165: TiXmlNode* TiXmlNode::LinkEndChild(TiXmlNode*): Assertion `node->parent == 0 || node->parent == this' failed.
#3  0x00007ffff4f6a192 in __GI___assert_fail (
    assertion=0x7ffff4605600 "node->parent == 0 || node->parent == this", 
    file=0x7ffff460546a "tinyxml.cpp", line=165, 
    function=0x7ffff4605740 "TiXmlNode* TiXmlNode::LinkEndChild(TiXmlNode*)") at assert.c:103
#4  0x00007ffff45fea15 in TiXmlNode::LinkEndChild(TiXmlNode*) () from /usr/lib/libtinyxml.so.2.6.2
#5  0x00007ffff5ee1ab7 in InsertSDFExtensionVisual(TiXmlElement*, std::string const&) ()
   from /usr/lib/libsdformat.so.1
#6  0x00007ffff5ee9990 in CreateVisual(TiXmlElement*, boost::shared_ptr<urdf::Link const>, boost::shared_ptr<urdf::Visual>, std::string const&) () from /usr/lib/libsdformat.so.1

I think this can be resolved by calling g_extensions.clear() in InitModelString, though I am not sure if there are any other ramifications of doing so (should be added right before L2552). As far as I can tell g_extensions should be used once per model and is only global for code convenience.

values.title: Include an optional "choices" atribute

content.raw:
Something like this:

```
#!c++
<attribute name="type" type="string" default="none" choices=("none", "gaussian", "gaussian_quantized") required="1">
    <description>
      The type of noise. Currently supported types are:
      "none" (no noise).
      "gaussian" (draw noise values independently for each measurement from a Gaussian distribution).
      "gaussian_quantized" ("gaussian" plus quantization of outputs (ie. rounding))
    </description>
</attribute>
```

Inspired by the *choices* keyword used in [argparse](http://docs.python.org/dev/library/argparse.html#choices).
content.html:
Something like this:

<attribute name="type" type="string" default="none" choices=("none", "gaussian", "gaussian_quantized") required="1">
    <description>
      The type of noise. Currently supported types are:
      "none" (no noise).
      "gaussian" (draw noise values independently for each measurement from a Gaussian distribution).
      "gaussian_quantized" ("gaussian" plus quantization of outputs (ie. rounding))
    </description>
</attribute>

Inspired by the choices keyword used in argparse.

values.title: readDoc function requires of an initialized parameter

content.raw:
When using the ```sdf::readFile``` or ```sdf::readDoc``` there is a ```sdf::SDFPtr``` parameter which should point to a valid SDF object and has been initialized using ```sdf::init()``` function. Otherwise user will get segfaults or errors.

We should found a better way of handling this need.
content.html:
When using the sdf::readFile or sdf::readDoc there is a sdf::SDFPtr parameter which should point to a valid SDF object and has been initialized using sdf::init() function. Otherwise user will get segfaults or errors.

We should found a better way of handling this need.

values.title: Attributes of child elements are not copied if no element description is available (gazebo issue 735)

content.raw:
Migrated from [gazebo issue 735](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/735):

Created by @johmeyer 



Attributes of unknown SDF elements (e.g. plugin configuration) should also be copied in the [sdf::copyChildren()](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/7d7b26034a43d88e48d490a660a591d3a6b338c1/src/parser.cc?at=default#cl-735) function in `src/parser.cc`. The current version only copies attributes of elements that have a description.

I am using attributes in some plugin configuration elements and it took me a while to find out why I cannot access them in the plugin's Load() method any more...

I am using Gazebo version 1.5 shipped with groovy. In fuerte, using the old parser_deprecated.cc that has been removed in [d7dbe92b6426674e33891035223605f390599dcb](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/commits/d7dbe92b6426674e33891035223605f390599dcb), having attributes in plugin child elements worked without problems.
content.html:
Migrated from gazebo issue 735:

Created by @johmeyer

Attributes of unknown SDF elements (e.g. plugin configuration) should also be copied in the sdf::copyChildren() function in src/parser.cc. The current version only copies attributes of elements that have a description.

I am using attributes in some plugin configuration elements and it took me a while to find out why I cannot access them in the plugin's Load() method any more...

I am using Gazebo version 1.5 shipped with groovy. In fuerte, using the old parser_deprecated.cc that has been removed in d7dbe92b6426674e33891035223605f390599dcb, having attributes in plugin child elements worked without problems.

values.title: parser_urdf inertial lumping for fixed joints is incorrect if inertia offset is non-zero
warning about non-sdf input should be demoted

content.raw:
When parsing something that's not SDF (e.g., `roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch`), I get this warning to console:

~~~
Warning [parser.cc:356] No <sdf> element in file[data-string]
~~~

Presumably, that's caused by the parser being given URDF, rather than SDF, input.  Given that we're still supporting URDF, it shouldn't be a warning.  Maybe an info statement, or better yet, just log it to file.

values.title: Visual pose is wrongly described in documentation

content.raw:
```
<visual>
	<pose>
	Description: Origin of the visual relative to its parent.
```

While in all other <pose> attributes the description states exactly where the origin is related to, in the <visual> one might (wrongly) assume that the <pose> is relative to the parent link associated by a joint <parrent> <child> relationship. 

It should change to

```
The reference frame of the visual element, relative to the reference frame of the link.
```
content.html:
<visual>
    <pose>
    Description: Origin of the visual relative to its parent.

While in all other <pose> attributes the description states exactly where the origin is related to, in the <visual> one might (wrongly) assume that the <pose> is relative to the parent link associated by a joint <parrent> <child> relationship.

It should change to

The reference frame of the visual element, relative to the reference frame of the link.

values.title: incompatibility between sdformat's URDF and github's URDF

content.raw:
There has been changes in some of the urdfdom_headers on github [1], and as a consequence, the urdf classes included in sdformat are not binary-compatible with those coming with ROS Hydro.

I have been fighting (hard) with really strange bugs as you can imagine before I ended up here. In a nutshell, I was working with a robot controller that parses urdf models, and that was running inside of gazebo. My controller used the headers and linked against the version of urdf tht is shipped with ROS Hydro, but the dynamic linking at runtime was done against the sdformat.so library, resulting in segfaults, very strange behaviors, and loss of hair on my part.

I can see two ways to solve this:

* update your version of urdf to match the *official* one
* stop using it altogether and declare it as an external dependency.

I would strongly suggest that the second option be chosen, especially since these packages are not ROS packages anymore. 

[1]: https://github.com/ros/urdfdom_headers/commit/eaa820b84e69c39e43452318ed07e7928eb1b577
content.html:
There has been changes in some of the urdfdom_headers on github 1, and as a consequence, the urdf classes included in sdformat are not binary-compatible with those coming with ROS Hydro.

I have been fighting (hard) with really strange bugs as you can imagine before I ended up here. In a nutshell, I was working with a robot controller that parses urdf models, and that was running inside of gazebo. My controller used the headers and linked against the version of urdf tht is shipped with ROS Hydro, but the dynamic linking at runtime was done against the sdformat.so library, resulting in segfaults, very strange behaviors, and loss of hair on my part.

I can see two ways to solve this:

  • update your version of urdf to match the official one
  • stop using it altogether and declare it as an external dependency.

I would strongly suggest that the second option be chosen, especially since these packages are not ROS packages anymore.

values.title: Copy simbody contact parameters to surface.sdf

content.raw:
Currently the simbody contact parameters are defined in [physics.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/f3d2a3bd5d80b14ad95781583ba802c8dafdbf74/sdf/1.4/physics.sdf?at=sdf_1.4#cl-46), so they can be specified globally. They should be copied to surface.sdf as well, so that they can be over-ridden for specific collision shapes.

Perhaps new sdf file should be created that is included in physics.sdf and surface.sdf to avoid duplication of code?
content.html:
Currently the simbody contact parameters are defined in physics.sdf, so they can be specified globally. They should be copied to surface.sdf as well, so that they can be over-ridden for specific collision shapes.

Perhaps new sdf file should be created that is included in physics.sdf and surface.sdf to avoid duplication of code?

values.title: Add Ability To Specify g_reduceFixedJoints in URDF2SDF

content.raw:
We ran into an issue where we require a one to one mapping between the source URDF and parsed SDF for a couple of places where we need to communicate joint names between a set of components that exclusively use the source URDF and another that must use with the parsed SDF. This issue only exists where joints are collapsed by the SDF parser.

Unfortunately the default and only constructor for URDF2SDF does not allow us to specify the value of g_reduceFixedJoints, which is explicitly set to true. As a workaround we have created a copy of the parser_urdf.cc and hh source and added a new constructor that allows the caller to specify the desired values for g_enforceLimits and g_reduceFixedJoints e.g.:

URDF2SDF::URDF2SDF(bool enforceLimits, bool reduceFixedJoints)

Everything seems to parse correctly and work as expected, is there a technical reason that setting these parameters is disallowed?
content.html:
We ran into an issue where we require a one to one mapping between the source URDF and parsed SDF for a couple of places where we need to communicate joint names between a set of components that exclusively use the source URDF and another that must use with the parsed SDF. This issue only exists where joints are collapsed by the SDF parser.

Unfortunately the default and only constructor for URDF2SDF does not allow us to specify the value of g_reduceFixedJoints, which is explicitly set to true. As a workaround we have created a copy of the parser_urdf.cc and hh source and added a new constructor that allows the caller to specify the desired values for g_enforceLimits and g_reduceFixedJoints e.g.:

URDF2SDF::URDF2SDF(bool enforceLimits, bool reduceFixedJoints)

Everything seems to parse correctly and work as expected, is there a technical reason that setting these parameters is disallowed?

values.title: Build fails on OSX 10.9 (Mavericks)

content.raw:
Compilation fails on OSX 10.9 (Mavericks), due to a reference in guest 1.6.0 to tr1 header files, while the standard C++ library on OSX 10.9 does not use tr1 headers anymore.

~~~
test/gtest/include/gtest/internal/gtest-port.h:499:13: fatal error: 
      'tr1/tuple' file not found
#   include <tr1/tuple>  // NOLINT
            ^
~~~

Updating to gtest 1.7.0 will fix it.
content.html:
Compilation fails on OSX 10.9 (Mavericks), due to a reference in guest 1.6.0 to tr1 header files, while the standard C++ library on OSX 10.9 does not use tr1 headers anymore.

      'tr1/tuple' file not found

            ^

values.title: "force_torque" sensors not handled by parser_urdf

content.raw:
Since the force_torque sensor type has been implemented in gazebo, this sensor type should be supported out of the box also by sdf.
Since at the moment this is not the case (as the documentation states), convertion of a .urdf robot description that uses force torque sensors to the .sdf format through gzsdf skips the force torque sensor definitions.
content.html: Since the force_torque sensor type has been implemented in gazebo, this sensor type should be supported out of the box also by sdf. Since at the moment this is not the case (as the documentation states), convertion of a .urdf robot description that uses force torque sensors to the .sdf format through gzsdf skips the force torque sensor definitions.

values.title: Documentation: list of sensor types is incomplete

content.raw:
There is a list of valid sensor types in [sensor.sdf](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/65b0b825ee1b9645907aec2810295cb445f4aac8/sdf/1.4/sensor.sdf?at=default#cl-9), but is incomplete.

camera, depth, multicamera, contact, gps, imu, ir and ray

$ grep -rnI GZ_REGISTER_STATIC_SENSOR gazebo/sensors | grep \" | sed -e 's@.*STATIC_SENSOR("@@' -e 's@",.*@@' | sort
camera
contact
depth
force_torque
gps
gpu_ray
imu
multicamera
ray
rfid
rfidtag
sonar
wireless_receiver
wireless_transmitter
~~~

values.title: Parse old versions of sdf files without warnings

content.raw:
Parsing an sdf file with an old version (currently anything earlier than 1.4) generates console warnings:
~~~
Warning [parser.cc:340] Converting a deprecated source[model.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:59]   Version[N] to Version[N+1]
~~~

Since we are providing backward compatibility through the `Converter` class, I think a warning message is not necessary. It also generates a lot of work upgrading models and world files in gazebo just so make the warnings go away when we do a version increment in sdformat.

I would propose converting these warnings to `sdfdbg`.
content.html:
Parsing an sdf file with an old version (currently anything earlier than 1.4) generates console warnings:

Warning [parser.cc:340] Converting a deprecated source[model.sdf].
Warning [Converter.cc:59]   Version[N] to Version[N+1]

Since we are providing backward compatibility through the Converter class, I think a warning message is not necessary. It also generates a lot of work upgrading models and world files in gazebo just so make the warnings go away when we do a version increment in sdformat.

I would propose converting these warnings to sdfdbg.

values.title: add spring stiffness and damper damping coefficients for joint

content.raw:
Proposed adding stiffness/reference position parameters for a joint:

~~~
<joint ...>
  <axis ...>
    <dynamics>
      <damping>...</damping>
      <friction>...</friction>
      <stiffness>[new stiffness coefficient]</stiffness>
      <reference>[new stiffness reference position]</reference>
    </dynamics>
  </axis>
</joint>
~~~

existing relevant coefficients:

  -  [joint limit `stiffness` and `dissipation`](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/e42c4aed49b2c2348c4f35c1c8c004b58af23196/sdf/1.4/joint.sdf?at=default#cl-66).
  - [surface `erp`, `cfm`, `kp`, `kd` for ode](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/e42c4aed49b2c2348c4f35c1c8c004b58af23196/sdf/1.4/surface.sdf?at=default#cl-59)
content.html:
Proposed adding stiffness/reference position parameters for a joint:

<joint ...>
  <axis ...>
    <dynamics>
      <damping>...</damping>
      <friction>...</friction>
      <stiffness>[new stiffness coefficient]</stiffness>
      <reference>[new stiffness reference position]</reference>
    </dynamics>
  </axis>
</joint>

existing relevant coefficients:

  • joint limit stiffness and dissipation.
  • surface erp, cfm, kp, kd for ode

values.title: sdf::Element::GetElement fails with undefined reference to `xmlCharStrdup` at runtime when used in plugin

content.raw:
I've written a gazebo model plugin which is linked against the libraries found by `find_package(gazebo)`. When I try to load this library, I get the following dynamic linker error when calling `sdf::Element::GetElement(...)`:

```
gzserver: symbol lookup error: /home/jbohren/ws/hydro/underlay/devel/lib/librtt_gazebo_deployer.so: undefined symbol: xmlCharStrdup
```

The libraries given by `find_package(gazebo)` are as follows:
```
 gazebo_transport;gazebo_physics;gazebo_sensors;gazebo_rendering;gazebo_gui;sdformat;gazebo_msgs;gazebo_math;gazebo_common;gazebo;/usr/lib/libgazebo.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_ccd.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_common.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_gimpact.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_gui.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_gui_building.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_gui_viewers.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_math.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_msgs.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_ode.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_opcode.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_opende_ou.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_physics.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_physics_ode.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_rendering.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_selection_buffer.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_sensors.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_skyx.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_transport.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_util.so;/usr/lib/libgazebo_player.so;optimized;/usr/lib/libprotobuf.so;debug;/usr/lib/libprotobuf.so;/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libsdformat.so
```

This is resolved only if I explicitly link my plugin against libxml2.

I'm building it in an isolated catkin workspace, and what's interesting is that if I build it in a non-isolated workspace, it loads with no trouble. This is probably a side-effect fixed by building it with another package without isolation.

values.title: add physics params corresponding to gazebo pull request #999
SDF_VERSION need to distinguish between protocol version and pkg version.

content.raw:
Since the 2.0.0 prerelease, the package version and the protocol version are not the same any more. Currently, the package is exporting SDF_VERSION in <sdf/config.h> using the version defined in root CMakeLists.txt which is also used for the package version.

We need to split into two different variables, one for pkg version (used by cpack) and another one which represent the protocol version.

To keep backwards compatibility, SDF_VERSION should be used to represent the protocol version, so the proposal would to create a SDF_PKG_MAJOR_VERSION, SDF_PKG_MINOR_VERSION, ... which will be used to create the package version.
content.html:
Since the 2.0.0 prerelease, the package version and the protocol version are not the same any more. Currently, the package is exporting SDF_VERSION in <sdf/config.h> using the version defined in root CMakeLists.txt which is also used for the package version.

We need to split into two different variables, one for pkg version (used by cpack) and another one which represent the protocol version.

To keep backwards compatibility, SDF_VERSION should be used to represent the protocol version, so the proposal would to create a SDF_PKG_MAJOR_VERSION, SDF_PKG_MINOR_VERSION, ... which will be used to create the package version.

values.title: Expose sdformat version number through API

content.raw: Should the sdf protocol version be accessed from a `#define` in a header file or a library call (ie. `std::string SDF::GetVersion()`)? Maybe it depends on the use case. But currently I think we don't have a way to query an sdformat library for its protocol version number; we can only get it from a header file.
content.html: Should the sdf protocol version be accessed from a #define in a header file or a library call (ie. std::string SDF::GetVersion())? Maybe it depends on the use case. But currently I think we don't have a way to query an sdformat library for its protocol version number; we can only get it from a header file.

values.title: Problem with Element::GetAttribute()/HasAttribute()/etc

content.raw:
If an sdf plugin tag has custom child tags, are those tags allowed to have attributes?

I tried loading some custom tags in a plugin, but the tag attributes don't seem to be loaded. If I put the same information in child tags it does work.

For example, SDF `Element::GetAttributeCount()` returns `0` for the following child tag of a plugin tag:
```xml
<custom foo="somevalue"/>
```
content.html:
If an sdf plugin tag has custom child tags, are those tags allowed to have attributes?

I tried loading some custom tags in a plugin, but the tag attributes don't seem to be loaded. If I put the same information in child tags it does work.

For example, SDF Element::GetAttributeCount() returns 0 for the following child tag of a plugin tag:

<custom foo="somevalue"/>

values.title: sdf::findFile search order is counter-intuitive and likely incorrect

content.raw:
Currently `sdf::findFile` searches system level directories before local, or custom path (`SDF_PATH`) specific ones. This prevents searches to non install locations from working correctly. 

Additionally it presupposes that the file being searched is below a parent directory "sdformat" when searching in below `SDF_SHARE_PATH`. `Converter::Converter` also prepends a parent called "sdformat" to queries doubling this path to "sdformat/sdformat/" causing it to fail in those cases.

These both directly affect the ability of the integration tests to function correctly for uninstalled builds on systems where there is an older/different system level build already installed. 

It is also likely cause problems outside of this scenario.

For backward compatibility the `sdformat` prepend should be kept, but an addional search should be done without it

The current order is:

 * URI
 * System unversioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat)
 * System versioned     (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat/x.x)
 * Custom
 * Absolute or Local

The order should probably be almost opposite with added paths to account for "sdformat" parent expectation seen below:

 * URI
 * Absolute or Local
 * Custom
 * raw System versioned  (SDF_SHARE_PATH/x.x)
 * prepended  System versioned   (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat/x.x)
 * raw System unversioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH)
 * prepended System unversioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat)
content.html:
Currently sdf::findFile searches system level directories before local, or custom path (SDF_PATH) specific ones. This prevents searches to non install locations from working correctly.

Additionally it presupposes that the file being searched is below a parent directory "sdformat" when searching in below SDF_SHARE_PATH. Converter::Converter also prepends a parent called "sdformat" to queries doubling this path to "sdformat/sdformat/" causing it to fail in those cases.

These both directly affect the ability of the integration tests to function correctly for uninstalled builds on systems where there is an older/different system level build already installed.

It is also likely cause problems outside of this scenario.

For backward compatibility the sdformat prepend should be kept, but an addional search should be done without it

The current order is:

  • URI
  • System unversioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat)
  • System versioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat/x.x)
  • Custom
  • Absolute or Local

The order should probably be almost opposite with added paths to account for "sdformat" parent expectation seen below:

  • URI
  • Absolute or Local
  • Custom
  • raw System versioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/x.x)
  • prepended System versioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat/x.x)
  • raw System unversioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH)
  • prepended System unversioned (SDF_SHARE_PATH/sdformat)

values.title: Converter's file search semantics are unclear and problematic

content.raw:
`Converter::Convert` appears to make unnecessary assumptions about the file structure which prevent use case where parent directory to version number is not "sdformat" which includes source builds which have not yet been installed where the parent directory is named "sdf".

Additionally `sdf::findFile` itself prepends "sdformat" when searching the SDF_SHARE_PATH and so searches will not match as they will end up prepended with "sdformat/sdformat"

This specific case prevents certain test cases from running correctly.

Some clients may rely on this behavior so it may make sense to create fix which searches multiple paths decendent to SDF

sdformat/src/Converter.cc
```
#!c++
std::string filename = sdf::findFile(  std::string("sdformat/") 
    + _toVersion + "/" + origVersion + ".convert");
```
content.html:
Converter::Convert appears to make unnecessary assumptions about the file structure which prevent use case where parent directory to version number is not "sdformat" which includes source builds which have not yet been installed where the parent directory is named "sdf".

Additionally sdf::findFile itself prepends "sdformat" when searching the SDF_SHARE_PATH and so searches will not match as they will end up prepended with "sdformat/sdformat"

This specific case prevents certain test cases from running correctly.

Some clients may rely on this behavior so it may make sense to create fix which searches multiple paths decendent to SDF

sdformat/src/Converter.cc

std::string filename = sdf::findFile(  std::string("sdformat/") 
    + _toVersion + "/" + origVersion + ".convert");

values.title: URDF parsing: contents of visuals in gazebo extension gets lumped to other visuals

content.raw:
For example, if I had an urdf with the following extension, to try and sneak sdf code into gazebo:
~~~
  <link name="l_foot">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1.634"/>
      <origin rpy="0 -0 0" xyz="0.027 0 -0.067"/>
      <inertia ixx="0.002" ixy="0" ixz="0" iyy="0.007" iyz="0" izz="0.008"/>
    </inertial>
    <visual>
      <origin rpy="0 -0 0" xyz="0 0 0"/>
      <geometry>
        <mesh filename="package://atlas_description/meshes/l_foot.dae" scale="1 1 1"/>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </link>
  <gazebo reference="l_foot">
    <visual name="l_foot_visual_soft">
      <pose>0.05 0 -0.05 0 0 0</pose>
      <geometry>
        <box>
          <size>0.4 0.175 0.125</size>
        </box>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </gazebo>
~~~
The sdf's [urdf parser lumps contents of visuals in extension](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/778bf6bc844dbff80ed6131627be1cc1618747c5/src/parser_urdf.cc?at=default#cl-1164) into the existing visual element of the urdf, resulting in a visual block that is a combination of the urdf visual and the sdf visual in the extension:
~~~
      <visual name='vis_l_foot_visual'>
        <pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <scale>1 1 1</scale>
            <uri>model://atlas_description/meshes/l_foot.dae</uri>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
        <pose>0.05 0 -0.05 0 -0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <box>
            <size>0.4 0.175 0.125</size>
          </box>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
~~~
Commenting out [this bit of special case code for `visual`](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/778bf6bc844dbff80ed6131627be1cc1618747c5/src/parser_urdf.cc?at=default#cl-1164) fixes this issue, but probably breaks something else.

We need a better way of adding sdf to models specified in urdf.  Especially when new things are introduced in sdf, pass it through from urdf in a more generic fashion.
content.html:
For example, if I had an urdf with the following extension, to try and sneak sdf code into gazebo:

  <link name="l_foot">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1.634"/>
      <origin rpy="0 -0 0" xyz="0.027 0 -0.067"/>
      <inertia ixx="0.002" ixy="0" ixz="0" iyy="0.007" iyz="0" izz="0.008"/>
    </inertial>
    <visual>
      <origin rpy="0 -0 0" xyz="0 0 0"/>
      <geometry>
        <mesh filename="package://atlas_description/meshes/l_foot.dae" scale="1 1 1"/>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </link>
  <gazebo reference="l_foot">
    <visual name="l_foot_visual_soft">
      <pose>0.05 0 -0.05 0 0 0</pose>
      <geometry>
        <box>
          <size>0.4 0.175 0.125</size>
        </box>
      </geometry>
    </visual>
  </gazebo>

The sdf's urdf parser lumps contents of visuals in extension into the existing visual element of the urdf, resulting in a visual block that is a combination of the urdf visual and the sdf visual in the extension:

      <visual name='vis_l_foot_visual'>
        <pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <scale>1 1 1</scale>
            <uri>model://atlas_description/meshes/l_foot.dae</uri>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
        <pose>0.05 0 -0.05 0 -0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <box>
            <size>0.4 0.175 0.125</size>
          </box>
        </geometry>
      </visual>

Commenting out this bit of special case code for visual fixes this issue, but probably breaks something else.

We need a better way of adding sdf to models specified in urdf. Especially when new things are introduced in sdf, pass it through from urdf in a more generic fashion.

values.title: Document primitive shape principle axis (e.g. how is orientation defined for a cylinder?)
Add bullet-specific tags

content.html:
Bullet's featherstone implementation uses a different implementation for rigid bodies using maximal coordinates (btRigidBody) and internal coordinates (btMultiBody). We should add a tag that will hint for bullet link/joint to prefer multi body vs. rigid body implementation.

We should also add a tag for specifying the breaking force in a bullet joint.

@erwincoumans

values.title: Ignores collision tags name attribute when converting URDF files

content.raw:
Converting from URDF to SDF ignores the name attribute of a link's collision tag and sets the name to <link_name>_collision. This causes problems when parts of the URDF such as the contact sensor reference the collision tag by name. In the attached file, it converts leftFingerCollision to leftFinger_collision.

Conversion output:

```
#!xml

$ gzsdf print simple-robot.urdf 
<sdf version='1.4'>
  <model name='GearsBot'>
    <link name='leftFinger'>
      <pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose>0.013123 -1.7347e-18 0.03315 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>0.049208</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>5.2203e-05</ixx>
          <ixy>-4.2027e-22</ixy>
          <ixz>1.0345e-05</ixz>
          <iyy>6.106e-05</iyy>
          <iyz>-2.2949e-21</iyz>
          <izz>1.018e-05</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
      <collision name='leftFinger_collision'>
        <pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <scale>1 1 1</scale>
            <uri>model://GearsBot/meshes/collision/leftFinger.STL</uri>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
        <surface>
          <contact>
            <ode/>
          </contact>
          <friction>
            <ode/>
          </friction>
        </surface>
      </collision>
      <visual name='leftFinger_visual'>
        <pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <geometry>
          <mesh>
            <scale>1 1 1</scale>
            <uri>model://GearsBot/meshes/collision/leftFinger.STL</uri>
          </mesh>
        </geometry>
      </visual>
      <gravity>1</gravity>
      <velocity_decay>
        <linear>0</linear>
        <angular>0</angular>
      </velocity_decay>
      <self_collide>0</self_collide>
      <sensor name='leftFingerContact' type='contact'>
        <always_on>1</always_on>
        <update_rate>100</update_rate>
        <contact>
          <collision>leftFingerCollision</collision>
          <topic>__default_topic__</topic>
        </contact>
      </sensor>
    </link>
  </model>
</sdf>
```
content.html:
Converting from URDF to SDF ignores the name attribute of a link's collision tag and sets the name to <link_name>_collision. This causes problems when parts of the URDF such as the contact sensor reference the collision tag by name. In the attached file, it converts leftFingerCollision to leftFinger_collision.

Conversion output:

    <link name='leftFinger'>
      <pose>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>

          <izz>1.018e-05</izz>

values.title: URDF conversion ignores fixed links

content.raw:
The URDF to SDF conversion fails when run in trusty and ignores fixed joints instead of collapsing them properly. This can be seen by running gzsdf print on the attached URDF. In trusty it looks the attached pacgoat-trusty.sdf when it should look like pacgoat-good.sdf

The first visible difference is that Chassis_collision_Bumpers is missing from the trusty version.

Suspicion is that this is related to the version of urdfdom distributed with trusty.

```
<link>
<pose frame="parent_link">x y z r p y</pose>
</link>
```

</link>

values.title: Pose tag in sensors ignored with fixed links

content.raw:
When a sensor (or at least camera's in this case) is attached to a fixed link, it's pose tag is ignored and overwritten with the computed pose for the fixed link when the pose tag should be transformed by the computed pose. I've attach the file to reproduce this issue. The following cases show the error. The pose should change, but doesn't.

No pose (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0):

    <sensor name="robotCamera" type="camera">
      <visualize>true</visualize>
      <!-- <pose>1 1 1 1.570796 1.570796 1.570796</pose> -->
      <camera></camera>
    </sensor>

Output:

    $ gz sdf -p /usr/share/frcsim/models/GearsBot/robots/GearsBot.URDF | awk "/<sensor name='robotCamera/,/<\/sensor>/"
      <sensor name='robotCamera' type='camera'>
        <visualize>1</visualize>
        <camera name='__default__'>
          <horizontal_fov>1.047</horizontal_fov>
          <image>
            <width>320</width>
            <height>240</height>
          </image>
          <clip>
            <near>0.1</near>
            <far>100</far>
          </clip>
        </camera>
        <pose>-0.20115 0.42488 0.30943 1.5708 -0.89012 1.5708</pose>
      </sensor>

Pose:

    <sensor name="robotCamera" type="camera">
      <visualize>true</visualize>
      <pose>1 1 1 1.570796 1.570796 1.570796</pose>
      <camera></camera>
    </sensor>

Output:

      $ gz sdf -p /usr/share/frcsim/models/GearsBot/robots/GearsBot.URDF | awk "/<sensor name='robotCamera/,/<\/sensor>/"
      <sensor name='robotCamera' type='camera'>
        <visualize>1</visualize>
        <camera name='__default__'>
          <horizontal_fov>1.047</horizontal_fov>
          <image>
            <width>320</width>
            <height>240</height>
          </image>
          <clip>
            <near>0.1</near>
            <far>100</far>
          </clip>
        </camera>
        <pose>-0.20115 0.42488 0.30943 1.5708 -0.89012 1.5708</pose>
      </sensor>
content.html:
When a sensor (or at least camera's in this case) is attached to a fixed link, it's pose tag is ignored and overwritten with the computed pose for the fixed link when the pose tag should be transformed by the computed pose. I've attach the file to reproduce this issue. The following cases show the error. The pose should change, but doesn't.

No pose (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0):

<sensor name="robotCamera" type="camera">
  <visualize>true</visualize>
  <!-- <pose>1 1 1 1.570796 1.570796 1.570796</pose> -->
  <camera></camera>
</sensor>

Output:

$ gz sdf -p /usr/share/frcsim/models/GearsBot/robots/GearsBot.URDF | awk "/<sensor name='robotCamera/,/<\/sensor>/"
  <sensor name='robotCamera' type='camera'>
    <visualize>1</visualize>
    <camera name='__default__'>
      <horizontal_fov>1.047</horizontal_fov>
      <image>
        <width>320</width>
        <height>240</height>
      </image>
      <clip>
        <near>0.1</near>
        <far>100</far>
      </clip>
    </camera>
    <pose>-0.20115 0.42488 0.30943 1.5708 -0.89012 1.5708</pose>
  </sensor>

Pose:

<sensor name="robotCamera" type="camera">
  <visualize>true</visualize>
  <pose>1 1 1 1.570796 1.570796 1.570796</pose>
  <camera></camera>
</sensor>

Output:

  $ gz sdf -p /usr/share/frcsim/models/GearsBot/robots/GearsBot.URDF | awk "/<sensor name='robotCamera/,/<\/sensor>/"
  <sensor name='robotCamera' type='camera'>
    <visualize>1</visualize>
    <camera name='__default__'>
      <horizontal_fov>1.047</horizontal_fov>
      <image>
        <width>320</width>
        <height>240</height>
      </image>
      <clip>
        <near>0.1</near>
        <far>100</far>
      </clip>

    <pose>-0.20115 0.42488 0.30943 1.5708 -0.89012 1.5708</pose>

values.title: Optionally use convex hull of mesh shapes

content.html:
There are computational advantages to collision detection using convex meshes. It would be useful for users who carefully construct their own convex meshes to be able to declare that they are convex. Then the collision engine can make smarter choices.

@erwincoumans @hsu

See also issue about gazebo-bullet concave mesh support for commentary on the challenges of real-time decomposition of concave meshes to convex. Using a flag will be computationally faster.

values.title: Incorrect URDF to SDF conversion of gravity and self_collide tags

content.raw:
Here is the [source](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/7074/urdf-to-sdf-conversion-using-gzsdf/#), and the specific part of the question:

**gravity, selfCollide and self_collide (gazebo tag for links)** 

Adding one of the tags above for a link, an additional tag is added to the resulting sdf file, i.e. there are then two gravity tags for the same link in the sdf file where the first is always set to true (1) and the second sdf tag holds the value set in the urdf. I assume that when gazebo parses the sdf file, it always finds the first tag using their value, thus always neglecting what has been set in the urdf.

and

**kp, kd (gazebo tag for joint)** 

Not converted into sdf. Why?

values.title: Search for urdfdom_headers when USE_EXTERNAL_URDF=True

values.title: URDF parsing seg-fault on OSX 10.8

content.html:
It's really weird; I'm only able reproduce this on my laptop running OSX 10.8.5. With the home-brew versions or urdfdom and console_bridge installed, and building the sdf_2.0 branch with -DUSE_EXTERNAL_URDF=True.

I observe seg-faulting of the INTEGRATION_fixed_joint_reduction and PERFORMANCE_parser_urdf tests.

From some extensive debugging, I've seen that the parser is unable to properly cast some of the URDF data types. For example, the cast from urdf::Geometry to urdf::Box in sdf::CreateGeometry is unsuccessful, which causes the seg-faults. The following is a workaround that prevents the seg-faults:

diff -r e874d482d50e src/parser_urdf.cc
--- a/src/parser_urdf.cc    Fri Sep 12 11:13:09 2014 -0700
+++ b/src/parser_urdf.cc    Wed Oct 01 14:31:48 2014 -0700
@@ -1673,9 +1673,19 @@
         box = boost::dynamic_pointer_cast< const urdf::Box >(_geom);
         int sizeCount = 3;
         double sizeVals[3];
-        sizeVals[0] = box->dim.x;
-        sizeVals[1] = box->dim.y;
-        sizeVals[2] = box->dim.z;
+        if (box)
+        {
+          sizeVals[0] = box->dim.x;
+          sizeVals[1] = box->dim.y;
+          sizeVals[2] = box->dim.z;
+        }
+        else
+        {
+          std::cerr << "Failed to cast to urdf::BoxPtr" << std::endl;
+          sizeVals[0] = 1.0;
+          sizeVals[1] = 1.0;
+          sizeVals[2] = 1.0;
+        }
         geometryType = new TiXmlElement(type);
         AddKeyValue(geometryType, "size",
             Values2str(sizeCount, sizeVals));

This is really weird.

values.title: Allow inclusion of links, collisions, and visuals

content.raw:
Right now `<include><uri>model://...` only facilitates inclusion of a whole model. 

We should add in the ability to include specific links, collisions, or visuals from a model.

For example, to include a specific collision:


```
#!c++

<include>
    <uri>model://MODEL_NAME/LINK_NAME/COLLISION_NAME</uri>
</include>
```
content.html:
Right now <include><uri>model://... only facilitates inclusion of a whole model.

We should add in the ability to include specific links, collisions, or visuals from a model.

For example, to include a specific collision:

<include>
    <uri>model://MODEL_NAME/LINK_NAME/COLLISION_NAME</uri>
</include>

values.title: INTEGRATION_provide_feedback test is broken

content.html:
I was planning to expand the INTEGRATION_provide_feedback test to test more joint parameters, but I discovered that the test isn't working properly. I've added some additional expectations in the patch below, and the test currently fails, possibly because the links have no inertial values.

diff -r e1bb1bc70356 test/integration/provide_feedback.cc
--- a/test/integration/provide_feedback.cc  Wed Oct 29 17:40:36 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/integration/provide_feedback.cc  Wed Oct 29 17:47:19 2014 -0700
@@ -46,17 +46,23 @@
   }

   sdf::ElementPtr model = robot->root->GetElement("model");
+  ASSERT_TRUE(model->HasElement("joint"));
+  unsigned int jointBitMask = 0;
   for (sdf::ElementPtr joint = model->GetElement("joint"); joint;
        joint = joint->GetNextElement("joint"))
   {
     std::string jointName = joint->Get<std::string>("name");
     if (jointName == "jointw0")
     {
+      jointBitMask |= 0x1;
+
       // No provide_feedback tag was specified
       EXPECT_FALSE(joint->HasElement("physics"));
     }
     else if (jointName == "joint01")
     {
+      jointBitMask |= 0x2;
+
       // provide_feedback = 0
       ASSERT_TRUE(joint->HasElement("physics"));
       sdf::ElementPtr physics = joint->GetElement("physics");
@@ -65,11 +71,18 @@
     }
     else if (jointName == "joint12")
     {
+      jointBitMask |= 0x4;
+
       // provide_feedback = 1
       ASSERT_TRUE(joint->HasElement("physics"));
       sdf::ElementPtr physics = joint->GetElement("physics");
       ASSERT_TRUE(physics->HasElement("provide_feedback"));
       EXPECT_TRUE(physics->Get<bool>("provide_feedback"));
     }
+    else
+    {
+      FAIL() << "Unexpected joint name[" << jointName << "]";
+    }
   }
+  EXPECT_EQ(jointBitMask, 0x7u);
 }

values.title: SDFormat fails to parse <visual> tag hierarchy when new SDF properties are added to <collision> tag hierarchy

content.raw:
After adding a bunch of new SDF properties to the <collision> tag hierarchy (specifically to the <surface> tag hierarchy, specification attached), SDFormat fails to parse the <visual> tag hierarchy if the <collision> tag hierarchy precedes the <visual> tag hierarchy. However, if the <visual> tag hierarchy is located before the <collision> tag hierarchy, both get parsed correctly.

There are no error or warning messages when the added SDF properties are present, the only obvious error is that no visual model is created when creating an instance of a corresponding model in a running Gazebo simulation.

Related to this issue, including output of "gz sdf --print path_to_model/model.sdf": [http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8098/problem-after-adding-properties-to-sdf-description/](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8098/problem-after-adding-properties-to-sdf-description/)
content.html:
After adding a bunch of new SDF properties to the <collision> tag hierarchy (specifically to the <surface> tag hierarchy, specification attached), SDFormat fails to parse the <visual> tag hierarchy if the <collision> tag hierarchy precedes the <visual> tag hierarchy. However, if the <visual> tag hierarchy is located before the <collision> tag hierarchy, both get parsed correctly.

There are no error or warning messages when the added SDF properties are present, the only obvious error is that no visual model is created when creating an instance of a corresponding model in a running Gazebo simulation.

Related to this issue, including output of "gz sdf --print path_to_model/model.sdf": http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8098/problem-after-adding-properties-to-sdf-description/

values.title: Allow physics presets to be <include>'ed

content.raw:
Physics presets were added in pull request #146 by @jacquelinekay and it would be very cool if users could create libraries of different physics presets that could be `<include>`'ed into world files.

For example, currently models can be inserted with:
~~~
<include>
  <name>cup_1</name>
  <uri>model://plastic_cup</uri>
  <pose>-0.8 250 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
</include>
~~~

If there was a an sdf file named `my_physics.sdf` like the following:
~~~
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <physics type="ode" name="my_physics">
    <gravity>0.000000 0.000000 -9.810000</gravity>
    <max_step_size>0.001000</max_step_size>
    <real_time_update_rate>1000</real_time_update_rate>
    <ode>
      <solver>
        <type>quick</type>
        <iters>100</iters>
        <precon_iters>0</precon_iters>
        <sor>1.000000</sor>
      </solver>
    </ode>
    <bullet>
      <solver>
        <type>sequential_impulse</type>
        <iters>100</iters>
        <sor>1.000000</sor>
      </solver>
    </bullet>
    <simbody>
      <accuracy>0.001</accuracy>
      <max_transient_velocity>0.01</max_transient_velocity>
    </simbody>
  </physics>
</sdf>
~~~
and if it was in the model database, perhaps it could be included like:
~~~
<include>
  <uri>model://my_physics</uri>
</include>
~~~

@rosebudflyaway
content.html:
Physics presets were added in pull request #146 by @jacquelinekay and it would be very cool if users could create libraries of different physics presets that could be <include>'ed into world files.

For example, currently models can be inserted with:

<include>
  <name>cup_1</name>
  <uri>model://plastic_cup</uri>
  <pose>-0.8 250 1.015 0 0 0</pose>
</include>

If there was a an sdf file named my_physics.sdf like the following:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <physics type="ode" name="my_physics">
    <gravity>0.000000 0.000000 -9.810000</gravity>
    <max_step_size>0.001000</max_step_size>
    <real_time_update_rate>1000</real_time_update_rate>
    <ode>
      <solver>
        <type>quick</type>
        <iters>100</iters>
        <precon_iters>0</precon_iters>
        <sor>1.000000</sor>
      </solver>
    </ode>
    <bullet>
      <solver>
        <type>sequential_impulse</type>
        <iters>100</iters>
        <sor>1.000000</sor>
      </solver>
    </bullet>
    <simbody>
      <accuracy>0.001</accuracy>
      <max_transient_velocity>0.01</max_transient_velocity>
    </simbody>
  </physics>
</sdf>

and if it was in the model database, perhaps it could be included like:

<include>
  <uri>model://my_physics</uri>
</include>

content.raw:
I am sorry if this is not the right place. I [asked on answers.gazebo.org about where to create a proposal to change the SDF spec](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8586/where-can-i-suggest-changes-to-the-sdf-spec) and someone suggested here. Since it seemed to be as good a suggestion as any, here I am.

The current <plugin> tag requires that a library name is given, and that library name must be a gazebo plugin. Plugin tags without a valid gazebo plugin generate an error.

I'm in a situation where we use SDF as an overall scene/world/robot description format in a robot framework (Rock, http://rock-robotics.org). We naturally started creating gazebo plugins for things that were missing (e.g. underwater thursters) but also wanted to add "plugins" for dealing externally with some things (for reasons that are beyond this proposal, we for instance want to simulate cameras outside of gazebo). We even had cases (the thrusters) where some parts of the infrastructure need to load plugins of their own, and need to know about the parameters given to the gazebo plugin.

In any case, to me, this is a matter of making SDF less gazebo-specific and more a general-purpose format, something it is already pretty good at. What I want to propose is to remove the 'file' attribute and instead define reserved tags within the <plugin> element:

```
<plugin name='thrusters'>
   <gazebo>libgazebo_thrusters.so</gazebo>
   <!-- name of the Rock task that can export this plugin to the outside world -->
   <rock>gazebo_thrusters::Task</rock>
</plugin>

```

A software environment would simply ignore a plugin tag which does not have the required inside tag (i.e. gazebo would ignore plugin elements that do not have a <gazebo> element and so on).

values.title: (SDF Spec) clarify the semantic of having multiple links in a model.

content.raw:
This is a follow-up to [this question](http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/8582/whats-the-semantic-of-having-multiple-toplevel/)

The current behaviour of Gazebo is that the first link inside a model defines the model's pose (i.e. the model's frame is rigidly attached to the link). However, subsequent links that are not attached to it through a joint are completely free. I am specifically referring to Gazebo, as [the SDF spec itself](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=model#model_link) is very unspecific about this issue. 

I find that quite a big magic, and very unintuitive. After reading quite a bit of Gazebo's API documentation, I, and other people within my team, went to the (wrong) conclusion that all "toplevel" links (links that are not children in a joint) would be fixed in the model frame.

I see two ways to solve this:
1. change the link behaviour
2. fix at least the SDF specification to clarify the relationship between links and model

I would personally very much prefer (1), but I guess that (2) would be the path of least resistance.
content.html:
This is a follow-up to this question

The current behaviour of Gazebo is that the first link inside a model defines the model's pose (i.e. the model's frame is rigidly attached to the link). However, subsequent links that are not attached to it through a joint are completely free. I am specifically referring to Gazebo, as the SDF spec itself is very unspecific about this issue.

I find that quite a big magic, and very unintuitive. After reading quite a bit of Gazebo's API documentation, I, and other people within my team, went to the (wrong) conclusion that all "toplevel" links (links that are not children in a joint) would be fixed in the model frame.

I see two ways to solve this: 1. change the link behaviour 2. fix at least the SDF specification to clarify the relationship between links and model

I would personally very much prefer (1), but I guess that (2) would be the path of least resistance.

values.title: allow multiple <inertial> blocks in a single Link element

content.raw:
This will make modeling slightly easier for end users. Currently, if a rigid body is composed of multiple simple geometries, user has to either:

  1. compute combined inertia by hand, or
  1. attach multiple links together with fixed joints

Allowing multiple `<inertial>` blocks in a single link will leverage `gazebo::Inertia` class to compute combined inertia.
content.html:

  1. compute combined inertia by hand, or
  2. attach multiple links together with fixed joints

Allowing multiple <inertial> blocks in a single link will leverage gazebo::Inertia class to compute combined inertia.

values.title: include friction model parameter for ODE

content.raw:
Add an element of `friction_model` to choose from pyramid, cone, and box friction model.  
Commit [bb5e2bb](https://bitbucket.org/rosebudflyaway/sdformat/commits/bb5e2bb55e386697e8832971b869c7a0d3f063a1) added the element. This is corresponding to Gazebo pull request [1522](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1522/cone-friction-model/diff#comment-6621619)

values.title: Windows linking error

content.raw:
Maybe it's a problem with my VM (Windows 8.1 on Parallels Desktop), but I just tried to rebuild sdformat on my windows VM, and it's giving boost linking errors. I configured it with `Debug` build type and it finds boost during configure ([configure log here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/ecdd052a1a8501c8e32f)). However, it gives "unresolved external" linking errors like the following during build ([build log here](https://gist.github.com/scpeters/46eac3ed03e1c0f3c356)):

~~~
Converter.cc.obj : error LNK2019:
 unresolved external symbol "__declspec(dllimport) public: __thiscall 
 boost::filesystem::directory_entry::directory_entry(void)" (__imp_??0directory_entry@filesystem@boost@@QAE@XZ)
 referenced in function "public: __thiscall boost::filesystem::detail::dir_itr_imp::dir_itr_imp(void)" (??0dir_itr_imp@detail@filesystem@boost@@QAE@XZ)
~~~

values.title: Deprecating sdf elements

content.raw:
It looks like setting `required="-1"` in an element description is [interpreted as a deprecation flag by the sdformat parser](#!/osrf/sdformat/src/1fe715d1c91a6057374055b92e75ae2b3cbc1529/src/parser.cc?at=default#cl-447). It also looks like the element will be skipped, so marking something as deprecated will provide a console message but will render the element unusable.

Perhaps we should add a new sdformat description attribute for deprecation? This way the value can still be parsed, while providing the warning message about deprecation.
content.html:
It looks like setting required="-1" in an element description is interpreted as a deprecation flag by the sdformat parser. It also looks like the element will be skipped, so marking something as deprecated will provide a console message but will render the element unusable.

Perhaps we should add a new sdformat description attribute for deprecation? This way the value can still be parsed, while providing the warning message about deprecation.

values.title: Screw Joint axis is always defined in model frame

content.raw: The axis of motion for screw joints seem to always be defined in the model frame instead of the child link frame, no matter what the <use_parent_model_frame> tag is set to. Rotating the link or joint frame seems to have no effect on the screw axis direction.
content.html: The axis of motion for screw joints seem to always be defined in the model frame instead of the child link frame, no matter what the <use_parent_model_frame> tag is set to. Rotating the link or joint frame seems to have no effect on the screw axis direction.

values.title: Gearbox joints violently explode when turned more then +-90 degrees about an axis other than the rotation axis

content.raw:
If a gearbox joint turns more than 90 degrees about an axis that it is not rotating on, ie the gearbox joint is on the x-axis and the robot turns about the z-axis, the robot starts violently jumping around.

This happens if:
 
* the model is physically rotated in the world
* it is started rotated in the .world file
* if the links that have the gearbox joints on them are rotated even if the model is not.

This can be seen in the attached file by rotating `joint_02` past the 90 degree mark. Before that point the other joints work fine but once it reaches there the links start flailing wildly
content.html:
If a gearbox joint turns more than 90 degrees about an axis that it is not rotating on, ie the gearbox joint is on the x-axis and the robot turns about the z-axis, the robot starts violently jumping around.

This happens if:

  • the model is physically rotated in the world
  • it is started rotated in the .world file
  • if the links that have the gearbox joints on them are rotated even if the model is not.

This can be seen in the attached file by rotating joint_02 past the 90 degree mark. Before that point the other joints work fine but once it reaches there the links start flailing wildly
